The planet formed from an enormous gas cloud 4. 5bn years ago under the feeble light of the newborn sun. The material leftover became the rest of the planets, the asteroids and the comets.
Jupiter, most likely the first planet formed after the sun, is believed to hold the keys to understanding the origins of our solar system.
Jupiter was formed from the sun's leftovers, creating a   planet that almost has its own mini solar system surrounding it.

To protect the spacecraft from the radiation, Juno has a shielded electronics vault.
Juno's most sensitive electronics are encased in a titanium vault to shield them from lethal radiation belts that are most intense around Jupiter's equator.

To protect the spacecraft during this period  --   and during its journey through the only    quiet zones of Jupiter's magnetic field  --   its important instruments are encased in a   titanium vault. The Galileo probe was the first to study Jupiter  from orbit.

The Galileo mission in the 1990s made some observations of the rings of dust and debris that surround Jupiter, but NASA scientists still don't know how close to the surface these get to the planet, nor do they know the distribution of material within them (some of the debris may be from meteorites captured in orbit around the planet).

In order for this needle threading to work, Juno's thrusters had to fire for more than 35 minutes to slow it down.
Launched in 2011 when Nasa faced a shortage of its favoured power source,   Juno relies on the sun's rays for energy and is already the most distant solar powered spacecraft from Earth.

Juno is plowing through this ring of debris with its engine nozzle cap off in preparation for Monday's burn.
